snippet: Washington’s traditionally cautious and pragmatic business lobby could slip into open warfare with the Tea Party faction of the Republican Party amid frustration over the crisis.
abstract: Some of country's most influential business executives are coming to the once-unthinkable conclusion that their voices carry little weight with House majority that their millions of dollars in campaign contributions helped build and sustain; Washington’s traditionally cautious and pragmatic business lobby could slip into open warfare with Tea Party faction of Republican Party amid frustration over fiscal crisis and threat of default.

byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON, NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and NELSON D. SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Eric Lipton reported from Washington, and Nicholas Confessore and Nelson D. Schwartz from New York.

lead_paragraph: Washington’s traditionally cautious and pragmatic business lobby could slip into open warfare with the Tea Party faction of the Republican Party amid frustration over the crisis.

headline.main: Business Groups See Loss of Sway Over House G.O.P.
headline.print_headline: Business Groups See Loss of Sway Over House G.O.P.
